comment._content: Looks like Steamboat Quay, with St Mary's in the background. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,557072,656884,7,9

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here's St Mary's from Sarsfield Bridge (the one you can see in the picture): maps.google.ie/maps?q=limerick&hl=en&ll=52.665348...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: There's nobody still milling flour in Ireland. You might be able to date it from the fact that the Newtown Perry mill is still in business in this photo.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The Flying Huntsman of Limerick is described in Freeman's in 1899 as a 'steam tug'. The earliest mention I can find of a steam tug of that name is in 1869 when it arrived in Belfast for the purpose of taking two tanks to Glasgow to lift a screw steamer which had sunk ten days previously in the Clyde.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Sad Fatality at Limerick Regatta Freeman's July 19th 1897

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to find a good news story about the Flying Huntsman...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
" ... The tug 'Flying Huntsman' was built in 1881 for the Clyde Shipping Co. and was acquired by the Limerick Towing Co. for Shannon Estuary towing duties in 1885. She passed to the Waterford SS Co. in 1893 and to the Limerick SS Co in 1907, lasting with them to just before WWI. She is described as an ugly vessel with two funnels abreast, ahead of the paddles. Limerick used her mainly for towing, but on occasion she was pressed into service carrying passengers on the Estuary. Iron hull with a single expansion engine, 122' x 20', built at South Shields. ... "
from - www.shipsnostalgia.com/showthread.php?t=11240 - about half way down page, post by Bruce Carson.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The Flying Huntsman is listed on Tyne Tugs, completed 1881. www.tynetugs.co.uk/flyinghuntsman1881.html The tug in this photo is twin-engined, so might not be the same vessel.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Twin funneled, at any rate. That tells you (potentially) how many boilers there were, but not necessarily how many engines.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I remember "Conqueror" on the Tyne in the 1950s, in the colours of France Fenwick. www.tynetugs.co.uk/conqueror1884.html Very similar to "Flying Huntsman". It would be a great project to build another.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Good news? 'Fraid not. The best I can do is neutral news of a tug doing her mundane job such as (Glasgow Herald, Feb 2 1883):
The barque Glenrosa, of and from Glasgow for Mauritius was left by the Clyde Shipping Company's Flying Huntsman on Wednesday 31st January , at 3 pm. WInd S
or (Glasgow Herald, Apr 25 1883)
The barque Sandringham, of and from Greenock for Quebec, was left by the Clyde Shipping Company's Flying Huntsman on Friday 20th inst at 7:30 pm, off AIlsa Craig. Wind westerly by northerly, light breeze

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Flying Huntsman Limerick Putt-putt-putt, whoop-whoop-whoop, chug chug - Ding-ding-ding, chooff-chooff-chooff, glug glug - The old paddle steamer - For a beautiful dreamer There's nothing quite like a good tug.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Email from David Waller, webmaster of Tyne Tugs.
"Yes, single cylinder, but two funnels and two paddles.  As I understand, the two funnels would be because there were two boilers, or just to add virtual power.  Two paddles and one cylinder needed some handling I believe, such as disconnecting one drive when needed."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks for going to that trouble! Very good of David to reply so speedily...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
